intro: Gossypium sturtianum var. nandewarense, commonly known as the Nandewar cotton, is a wild cotton species native to the arid regions of Australia. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves, which are adapted to withstand harsh environmental conditions. The plant produces small, pale green flowers that develop into capsules containing fluffy, white fibers. These fibers are similar to those of cultivated cotton but are less commercially viable due to lower yield and quality. It plays an important role in the ecological and botanical study of wild cotton species in semi-arid ecosystems.
